Connect to Remote Shell

TIBCO Enterprise Administrator shell is a remote shell based on SSH. Follow these steps to connect to the remote TEA SSH server.

  1. Use your favourite terminal program (Putty or Terminal).
  2. Connect to the remote TEA SSH server using the command ssh -p 2222 admin@localhost :
  3. Enter the password admin

Upon successful connection, you will see this banner. 

 _____ _____    _      ____  _          _ _
|_   _| ____|  / \    / ___|| |__   ___| | |
  | | |  _|   / _ \   \___ \| '_ \ / _ \ | |
  | | | |___ / ___ \   ___) | | | |  __/ | |
  |_| |_____/_/   \_\ |____/|_| |_|\___|_|_|

TEA shell v2.1.0

Hit '<tab>' for a list of available commands
    and '[cmd] --help' for help on a specific command.
    or 'help [cmd]' to get detailed help on the command with samples.
    Run 'logout' or 'exit' to exit the shell.

Commands

Navigation

Navigating through the object hierarchy on the TEA Server is quite similar to navigating a file system. Each object has a path corresponding to it and using the 'cd' command one can navigate to the object.

Following are commands which are helpful for navigation:

  • ls

    Lists the members contained in a TEA object at the specified path.

  • cd

    Navigate to the TEA object at the specified path.

  • pwd

    Print the path of the current TEA object.

Help

To get comprehensive help using a command, use the --help option with the command.

Help prints out the following details of the command:

  • Description
  • Name and description of Arguments
  • Name, description and aliases for Options
  • Syntax for usage

To get more details about the command including description and examples, use help 'command name'.

Displays detailed description of the command. For example:

  • Detailed description of the command
  • Examples of the command

Following is the output for the command 'cd --help'

NAME
        tea:cd

    Changes the context to the given path

SYNTAX
        tea:cd [path]

ARGUMENTS
        path
                Target path to which to change the context to.

Following is the output for the command 'help cd'

NAME
        tea:cd

	Changes the context to the given path

SYNTAX
        tea:cd [path]

ARGUMENTS
        path
                Target path to which to change the context to.


DESCRIPTION
        Change Directory - change the current working directory to a specific Folder.
        If directory is not given, the current working directory is not changed.

SAMPLES
        1. Do cd command in TEA server without argument:

        admin@localhost.local:/>cd
        admin@localhost.local:/>
        admin@localhost.local:/>pwd
        /

        2. Do cd command in TEA server with optional argument [path] to change to another path:

        admin@localhost.local:/>cd TEA
        admin@localhost.local:/TEA>
        admin@localhost.local:/TEA>pwd
        /TEA

        3. Do cd command in TEA server to move up one path:

        admin@localhost.local:/TEA>cd ..
        admin@localhost.local:/>
        admin@localhost.local:/>pwd
        /

Shell Language

The command language supports some advanced constructs which help in scripting. Using these constructs one can combine multiple commands and write complex scripts.

Following is a list of supported constructs:

  • Arrays

    Arrays can be passed as arguments to some commands

    Usage
    • echo [ 'a' 'b' 'c']

  • Multiple Commands

    Multiple commands can be run by separating them with a ';'

    Usage
    • cd /TEA; ls

  • Pipes

    Output of one command can be piped to the input of another command using a '|'

    Usage
    • ls TEA/members/Roles | grep a
      • TEA_ADMIN
      Tomcat Admin
      Tomcat User

  • Closures

    Closures are functions which can be invoked with arguments. One can define the functions at runtime and invoked them at runtime. '{' and '}' are used to enclose a closure definition.

    Usage
    • admin@localhost:/TEA> each {ls}{show info $it}
      • Name:TEA
      Type:tea:2.1.0:TEA
      Status:Running

      Name:Agents
      Type:tea:2.1.0:agents

      Name:Users
      Type:tea:2.1.0:users

      Name:Groups
      Type:tea:2.1.0:groups

      Name:Roles
      Type:tea:2.1.0:roles

      Name:Realms
      Type:tea:2.1.0:realms

      Name:Machines
      Type:tea:2.1.0:teaMachines

      Name:Solutions
      Type:tea:2.1.0:solutions

  • Json ComplexType

    If the definition of a particular TeaParam of a TeaOperation is an user defined object then on shell side user should input a string in Json complexType format.

    Usage
    • '{"strA":"aa","strB":"bb"}'

    Note: Use single quotation marks to wrap the JSON input in the single command mode. In the interactive mode, do not use quotation marks.

Advanced Commands

The command language supports some advanced constructs which help in scripting. Using these constructs one can combine multiple commands and write complex scripts.

Following is a list of supported constructs:

  • each

    Invokes a given function (i.e. closure) on each of the elements in the given array.

    Usage
    each values function
    • The 'values' parameter can be an array or a closure which evaluates to an array
    • The 'function' parameter is a closure which should be invoked on each element
    Example
    • each [Jan Feb Mar] { echo $it}
    • each { ls } {show info $it}

  • if

    Command to support conditional execution

    Usage
    if condition ifTrue [ifFalse]
    Example
    • if { echo true } { echo 'true' } { echo 'false' }

  • sort

    Sort the input objects

    Usage
    tea:sort [options]
    Options
    --ignore-leading-blanks, -b
    ignore leading blanks
    --numeric-sort, -n
    compare according to string numerical value
    --unique, -u
    output only the first of an equal run
    --reverse, -r
    reverse the result of comparisons
    --ignore-case, -f
    fold lower case to upper case characters
    Example
    1. Do sort command in TEA server shell terminal with ls command plus pipe:
    admin@localhost.local:/TEA/members>ls | sort -r
    Users
    Solutions
    SearchViewManager
    Roles
    Realms
    Permissions
    OperatorViewManager
    Machines
    Groups
    Agents

  • set

    Sets a particular option in current session

    Usage
    tea:set [options]
    Options
    --scope
    Global scope name to set for current session
    Example
    1. Set "tomcat" as the current global session scope, while being under / path:

    admin@localhost.local:/>set --scope tomcat
    Successfully set the current scope to tomcat

    2. Set "NULL" as the current global session scope means reset the scope back to empty:

    admin@localhost.local:/>set --scope NULL
    Successfully reset the current scope back to empty.

  • get

    Gets the current value of a supported option, from current session

    Usage
    tea:get [options]
    Options
    --scope
    Requests the current value of global scope stored in session
    Example
    1. Get the current global session scope, while being under /TEA path:
    admin@localhost.local:/TEA>get --scope
    Current scope is: tomcat

Direct command & script file support

Tea shell supports executing direct command and script file from input

Following are description for these two usages:

  • direct command

    Usage
    ssh -p2222 admin@localhost ls
    Output
    TEA

  • script file

    Content of script.txt
    ls pwd history
    Usage
    ssh -p2222 admin@localhost scriptmode < script.txt
    Output
    ls
    TEA

    pwd
    /
    history
    0 ls
    1 pwd
    2 history

SFTP & SCP support

Tea server supports SFTP & SCP protocol.

Following are description for the usage:

When the SFTP connected you can type in help after sftp prompt to get detailed usage.

  • sftp command

    Usage
    sftp -P 2222 admin@localhost
    Output
    sftp>
    Upload and download file
    sftp> put /Users/myname/a.txt
    Uploading /Users/myname/a.txt to /a.txt
    /Users/myname/a.txt 100% 934 0.9KB/s 00:00
    sftp> ls
    a.txt
    sftp> get a.txt
    Fetching /a.txt to a.txt
    /a.txt

  • scp command

    Usage
    scp -P 2222 a.xml admin@localhost:/a.xml
    Output
    a.xml 100% 11KB 11.3KB/s 00:00

Position & Named argument support

Tea shell support positional and named argument for TeaParam.

Following is the usage for how to define the TeaParam and how to use it in shell.

  • Position only

    TeaParam definition
    public String testA(@TeaParam(name = "aa", description = "Greetings parameter", alias = "") final long[] greetings)
    Usage
    shell> testA [12 15]

  • Position & Named with no alias defined

    TeaParam definition
    public String testA(@TeaParam(name = "aa", description = "Greetings parameter") final long[] greetings)
    Usage
    shell> testA [12 15]
    shell> testA -aa [12 15]
    shell> testA --aa [12 15]

  • Position & Named with alias defined

    TeaParam definition
    public String testA(@TeaParam(name = "aa", description = "Greetings parameter", alias="bb") final long[] greetings)
    Usage
    shell> testA [12 15]
    shell> testA -aa [12 15]
    shell> testA --aa [12 15]
    shell> testA -bb [12 15]
    shell> testA --bb [12 15]

  • Named Only

    TeaParam definition
    public String testA(@TeaParam(name = "aa", description = "Greetings parameter", alias="aa") final long[] greetings)
    Usage
    shell> testA -aa [12 15]
    shell> testA --aa [12 15]

Command Completion

Completion for commands is available. Completion can be triggered by entering <tab>

Following completions are supported:

  • Command Names
  • Argument completion for path-based commands like ls, cd, show status and show info,

Support for interactive arguments

The user can execute a command by entering each argument when being prompted to.

Example: For a command create which takes arg1 and arg2 as parameters
One can enter the parameters in an interactive mode on the console, like this:

create

arg1:foo

arg2:bar

foo bar

Support for Binding Session Variables to Arguments

For an operation defined on agent this way:create(@TeaParam(name="type") String type, @TeaParam(name="name") String name, @TeaParam(name="domain", alias="d") String domain);, it is possible to invoke it as shown below:
domain = QA-Domain
create appspace HR-AppSpace

Working with sample agent

This section describes the typical usage of commands when working with the sample agent.

Register

Following are the steps to register the sample agent:

  1. Start the sample 'HelloWorld' agent. Lets assume that the agent is running at the url http://localhost:1234/helloworldagent

  2. Navigate to the root of the object hierarchy

    cd TEA/agents/

  3. Invoke the command to register the agent

    registeragent helloworldagent2 http://localhost:1234/helloworldagent

  4. Verify if the agent was registered. Check the members at the path /TEA/agents

    ls /TEA/agents

Manage

Following are the steps to manage the sample agent:

  1. Check the status of the agent. Whether it is registered or not.

    show status /TEA/agents/helloworldagent2

  2. Reload the agent.

    cd /TEA/agents/helloworldagent2; reload

  3. Unregister the agent.

    cd /TEA/agents/helloworldagent2; unregister
